etymologies: late 18th century; earliest use found in William Roxburgh (1751–1815), botanist. From scientific Latin Butea (attributed to J. G. König by W. Roxburgh in Asiatick Researches 3 469) from the title of John Stuart, Earl of Bute + -a

definitions: Any of various trees or climbing plants of the genus Butea (family Fabaceae (Leguminosae)) of southern and south-eastern Asia, especially B. monosperma (also called dhak, palas, and flame of the forest).
In full "butea gum". A resin or gum obtained from Butea monosperma.
